title: How storytellers can thrive in business (with Trilith Studios' Frank Patterson) | Masters of Scale

rawLines.text: [Music]
Hey folks, Jeff Berman here. This week
on the show, we hear extraordinary
stories and insight from the legendary
Frank Patterson. He's the CEO of Trilith
Studios, the beating heart of Georgia's
growing film business just south of
Atlanta. Trilith spans hundreds of
acres, boasts more than 30 studios, and
is home to a growing number of
incredible creators. Trilith is also
home to some of Marvel's biggest films
and takes an innovative approach to
nurturing a new generation of filmmakers
and creators. That piece, the nurturing
that next generation of filmmakers and
creators is core to Frank. He's a
professor and dean ameritus at Florida
State's film school and has mentored
hundreds if not thousands of young
people who are changing the face of the
entertainment industry. Frank joined us
live on stage in Atlanta at the historic
Fox Theater. It's the latest in our
Masters of Scale live series presented
by Capital 1
Business. This is Masters of Scale.
Good evening, Atlanta. How are we doing?
You spent a career um telling stories
and helping tell stories. Um and and
part of our theme tonight is about world
building. And I'm I'm curious um what's
what's your first memory of seeing a
world built on a screen that just took
your breath away? 2001, A Space Odyssey.
Uh my mom, now I didn't know this at the
time. She was trying to get away from my
dad. So we went to a theater and we
watched that film. I think I was
eight.
And I'll never forget it. I mean, it's
easy to say Kubric, you know, but that
that one shot of of the ship going
across the screen and the sort of
feeling of the world that he was asking
us to consider, I didn't obviously
didn't understand it at 8, but it just a
memory I'll never forget. Frank, at the
risk of of getting too personal too
early. Okay, we're among friends here.
We are among friends. Um, when you say
your mom was uh trying to get away from
your dad, what what do you mean by that?
Uh well um you know as an adult looking
back my dad's no longer with us. I I
learned that he struggled with a lot of
sickness uh a lot of mental health
problems and so you know my parents
ended up
not their marriage didn't survive. Uh
and um you know my mom
was you know an important person in my
life and uh
so you know the things that I saw as
sort of adventures like going to see you
know 2001 space odyssey uh you know
turned out to be really valuable for me.
um and
um that uh world that I grew up in where
there was all this tension and you know
uh I had an English teacher in high
school who said uh pulled me aside. I
grew up in a little town in Texas and uh
he said you know you're you're a
storyteller. This is you know thank
goodness for an English teacher to come
in and say you are a storyteller. Get
out of this town.
do not grow up here. Yeah. You know, and
I got a writing scholarship to school
and I think everything that I grew up in
was, you know, as an adult looking back,
it was a gift, right? How do you end up
running a massive studio? Like, how how
do you get from from there to where we
are today? I think it was very helpful
that I was focused early
on on how to tell a story. You know,
that story was important to me because
no matter where you end up in this
industry, the real currency is the
ability to tell a story. And whether
you're an production accountant who's
trying to understand why a director made
a decision to purchase something or
you're, you know, you're a writer,
director, it is everything. It's
everything that we breathe and leave.
And and we haven't been doing a great
job of it lately as an industry, but we
are have some young people that are
doing some very cool things. But the
bottom line is I think it was very
helpful for me to to grow up as focus on
story. Then as I learned the craft I
began to realize all these other parts
of the industry and to be honest with
you I was never the best person. I was
not a good athlete but I was always on
the team. Uh and I knew how to pull good
teams together. Uh I
was on all the clubs I was a part of. I
I was just lucky to be a part of it but
I knew how to pull things together. So I
began to realize that kind of my talent
is recognizing talent, right? Uh and
main mainly just because I'm a good
audience. I I love talent. Uh uh
so when I began to realize, wait a
minute, I'm really more of a producer
entrepreneur. And uh so then I started a
couple of production businesses and
realized, wait a minute, I should do
more than one film at a time. And I
began to think of the industry as uh as
an industry that has a really incredible
social impact if you're handling it the
right way, right? And uh I I think uh
through several startups uh some
failures, some wins. Uh I uh uh met um
uh who was then the Pinewood team.
Pinewood is an iconic British film
studio that partnered in the creation of
the Georgia location. Pinewood sold at
stake and the facilities were rebranded
as Trilith Studios in 2020. Uh James
Vaughn Movies, you've probably all heard
of them, uh formed uh here a partnership
with Dan Kathy here in Atlanta to form
Pinewood Atlanta Studios. And really
Pinewood was operating it from London,
right? And it was a facilities
organization. And when you say
facilities organization, what does that
mean?
Um, it's like renting hotel rooms,
right? You you're just providing
facilities to productions to execute on
their production, right? Uh, and at the
time the studio was looking for its
first leader. Uh, and um, I happened to
uh, I had given this keynote speech at
the innovation summit in Zurich. Then
Dan just showed up in my office one day
and said, you know, the way you're
thinking about industry, you know, we're
looking for a leader and would like to,
you know, I like to, as a lot of
entrepreneurs say, we like to go where
the puck is going and not where it is.
And he invited me to come, Les and my
wife Lesley and I to come visit. And um
I met the Pinewood team, uh which I
thought was very nice, but I wasn't
interested in running facilities. Why
not? Uh I I I don't know that business.
I'm a I'm a filmmaker and an
entrepreneur and a technologist. At that
time, I had uh just exited a technology
company that was making digital humans.
And I wasn't really focused on running
facilities. But you know, Dan said
something kind of important to me in
that first meeting. Think of this as a
700 acre campus that you can paint as an
entrepreneur. I thought, okay, now
that's interesting. He even said, why
don't you grab your team from San
Francisco and have them move here and
build digital humans here? And I
thought, okay, he's being serious about
this. Like, we should think about this.
So, let's just I just want to dial in
real quick. When you say digital humans,
you don't mean like literal robots
walking around. No. Okay. So, uh I was
co-founder and uh CEO of a company that
we called them hyperrealistic digital
humans. Uh, and um, we created the
Michael Jackson that appeared at the
Billboard Music Awards in 2014. Um, and
uh, you know, that was 9 years after
Michael's death. It was an original
song. Um, it was an original
performance. Um, and so we did that. It
scared I scared the life out of me cuz
by the way, in dress rehearsal, that
performance didn't work. Oh, yeah. So
there were only there were only 11
million people watching and 10,000
people live. What went What went wrong?
It just didn't work. It just didn't
work. Yeah. We were putting together a
lot of technologies that
that didn't want to play nice with each
other. Yeah. An unstable stack. A very
unstable stack. And it just didn't work
at dress rehearsal. And uh but anyway,
uh so that was a a very challenging time
because it was a startup. We were
emerging technology. We didn't have a
product market fit. We didn't really
like tell me where digital humans belong
right now. Right. Well, then this is
this is also 10 years plus ago. 10 years
ago, right? Yeah. So, we didn't have
product market fit. There was one night
back in April. I was just telling my
team about this the other day, you know,
sometime April, it was 2014. I was out
of cash. I had to pull RA payroll. It's
a Thursday night for Friday payroll.
Yep. Every entrepreneur who's been in
this room I I'm not going to ask for a
raise of hands, but I'm sure there are a
few here. And because we were doing
animation at the highest levels, we were
literally
animating one of the most famous faces
in the world and and we were out of
money and there was that really awkward
moment that I had to am I going to pull
payroll which is by the way going to hit
the bank account on Monday and I don't
have the finances to cover. I do have a
hard lender who's agreed to leverage my
house. I haven't told my wife about that
yet. So I could lose my business.
Breaking news, Leslie. Yeah, I can lose
my business, my house, and my wife if
this goes wrong. So, you know, but if I
don't pull payroll, this is a very
high-profile company because our uh six
of our artists were some of the most
famous animator artists in the industry.
That's the only way we were able to pull
off Michael Jackson at that time. So, if
I don't pull payroll, it's going to be
in the trades in the morning and my
business is over. Yeah. Right. So,
needless to say, I pulled payroll. Yep.
And we can talk about later about what
happened. But anyway, we got through it.
Uh and but it was a very very much a
startup business and uh we we created
some really wonderful tech and by the
way in the end it worked out. We had a
nice exit out of it. Um but imagine
coming off the heels of that and saying
let's run facilities, right? Like that's
not the plan. And so I think I think
what was exciting about my partnership
with Dan was Dan as a lot of people in
this town know uh you know Chick-fil-A
is an amazing business right and Dan's
an amazing leader he was basically
saying look just paint brother just
paint do you know because he didn't come
from the film industry right but he
loves it he loves storytelling and so
that's I think the good fortune for me
was to have that platform to say okay
now let's start start investing in
content companies and technology
companies and Let's build a place where
you know that that that really is a a
platform for storytellers that what's al
ultimately become a city for
storytellers. A place that you know is
really unique. I think when you came
here and you saw this canvas and you
were able to envision as a canvas what
what were you able to see that you could
build here that made it worth moving
cross country and starting a new life
here? It was basically uh um if we made
some bets into some emerging content
companies and bets into some emerging
tech companies at this place that's 20
minutes from the most traveled airport
in the world that has a great culture
and a history of innovation. I bet we
could go where opportunity is. And so
that's kind of where I felt like okay
let's do this. Um, and fortunately at
the time the the Pinewood uh uh uh CEO
and and and investors at that time, you
know, was excited about it. Now they
recapped they wanted to focus on
facilities and we ended up separating,
you know, buying them out. Um but Ivan
Dunley, who was the CEO of of um
Pinewood at the time, really like this
idea of being entrepreneurial and
erecting this these other businesses and
figuring out how to build this
opportunity. So, this was in the in the
201s, 2016, I think. Yeah. When um the
the joke in Hollywood was you would uh
show up at Sunset and Gower, walk in the
door, and they'd say, "Welcome to
Netflix. You're green lit." Right. Um
you know, everything was getting made.
That's right. Um uh the last few years
have been a little It's a different
environment. Yeah. So, um h how have you
weathered that? What surprised you? And
what what are you doing differently in
this in this postcoavid post strike, you
know, cut back on content spend world
that we're now in? Well, the stuff that
didn't surprise there was things that
did really surprise us all, which is you
just mentioned them, right? The
pandemic, right?
Um the the stuff that didn't surprise us
was, you know, Hollywood has this habit
of and and a lot of industries are
guilty of this, but we in the film
industry are are very guilty of this.
Spending like drunken sailors waking up
hung over. You know, it's like, oh,
guess what? You got to pay for this,
right? We had the good fortune at
Trilith of being, you know, home to some
of the biggest movies in the industry. a
lot of Marvel product as I think
everybody here knows. Um but we knew
that there was going to be a correction
and we have recently really widened the
aperture of kind of storytellers and
businesses that we focused on to support
now. Yeah. Let's build off of that. Um
uh nearly 10 years in here. Um what what
is Trilith today?
Great. It's this
place that has everything great
storytellers need to do anything they
can
imagine. And by the way, a little
exaggeration because we don't have
everything yet. I'd say that that's our
vision, but we have like
75% of everything. We have some of the
most amazing technology. We have some of
the most amazing homes and a town. We we
are a city of storytellers. And that we
figure if we can do that, wrap ourselves
around the the current and next
generation of storytellers and really
have ignite this uh creative market
ecosystem that we have. You know, what
are the businesses and the brains that
you put into this place that together
provide everything that a great
storyteller needs to do anything they
can imagine. So on one hand we have
James Gun and we have uh an up andcoming
filmmaker named Demetrius Win who's in
the audience, right?
And we we we
have everywhere, you know, that we want
to be home to those storytellers. And
and I grew up, you know, when I first
moved to Hollywood, you know, the
soundstages were two blocks away. There
was a camera house four blocks away.
Post was just over the hill in Burbank.
Basically, everything you needed was
there. Yeah. And it was a time and a
place in Hollywood where a kid who was
poor, broke from Texas, could actually
live there. Yeah, that's very hard to do
today. Well, and I think part part of
what I'm hearing is important about this
is is the physical proximity made a
difference. Absolutely. When we talk
about everything someone needs to do, do
anything they can imagine. You also have
to think about how people live,
where they live. Our industry is tough
on families because we're traveling all
the time, right? Four months away for a
movie. It's brutal, right? But we have a
town. Come visit y'all if y'all hadn't
seen it. We think about where they live,
where their kids go to school, what they
eat. We have a 65,000 foot wellness
center that when a crew comes in, when
you have 5,500 people on the lot working
every day, every crew member on that lot
has a free membership to a worldclass
wellness center. Definitely, we have all
the technology and the cameras and
lights and transpo and everything. You
know, we have, I think, 67 businesses at
Trrellith that range from the largest
lighting and grip company to the best
doughnut shop, you know, in the world.
Literally a kindergarten there, too. I
mean, right. So, we have a not just a
kindergarten, we have a it's called the
Forest School. It's a K through 12. So,
I think the idea
of having all of those resources is what
makes it work and not simply great sound
stages and great technology. Right. For
the second half of our conversation with
Frank Patterson, we asked Christina Ren
to join us on stage. Christina is an
actress, filmmaker, and entrepreneur who
has made a home and is working in the
trilith community. You may have seen her
in Zack Snider's Man of Steel or in
ABC's Will Trent. She also runs a
startup, a production company with her
husband. Tell us, Christine, about your
experience here because um you you you
didn't grow up in Georgia. Um, you
didn't you went to Tish, right? Um,
where my son is going in the fall.
Congratulations. Proud dad moment. Um, h
how did you end up here? Uh, Frank
really. And, um, Kelly, who is here in
the audience, my husband's aunt. Uh, we
were in Los Angeles and, um,
contemplating moving back to New York
because our family's on the East Coast.
Um, and Kelly called up my husband and
and she says, "You have to look at what
they're doing in Atlanta. Look at what
they're doing down in Fagatville and he
looks it up and he goes, "Frank is
running this." Um, because he went to
Florida State while Frank was the dean
there and they were very close. So he
text Frank and um who I had enjoyed also
getting to know over the years and uh
you know you you said come on down and
showed him around and he immediately he
came home and said we got to we got to
move there. It's amazing what they're
doing and um yeah he he pitched me and
sold me and so it's been almost three
years and we've really enjoyed being
down here. Christina, one of the things
that I'm I'm struck by from Frank's
narrative, um, is is as a as a creator,
as a storyteller, then having to
actually learn the business side of it.
And I I think for a lot of
entrepreneurs, they they have a spark
and idea or they're a technologist,
whatever it might be, but then all of a
sudden the reality of actually having to
build and run a business comes along.
What's what's that? We talk about the
business that you and your husband have
and and what's it been like going on
that part of the journey for you? Yeah.
So, we have a production company, Two
Kids with a Camera that we started
uh in
2010ish. Um, and so, uh, you know, we
make, uh, films and streaming series and
such, but we also do a lot of, uh,
branded content for big, uh, corporate
clients. So, we have something for
American Express right now and Lowe's,
Cisco, etc. Um, and so for us, you know,
we started very small. And so I think
for us it's been a a natural build over
time and that has been very successful.
We didn't like pitch really big and run
an office in Soho and then like run
ourselves into the ground really
quickly. Um and that has been I think
maybe our strongest suit. And I think
because we center story, because you
know of our backgrounds, if we can bring
that to our clients and say story is how
you're going to connect with people,
whether it's at your live event or as
you're trying to share the information
that you guys have been researching, um
you will connect and your um information
will land in a deeper way. And so yeah,
there's so much that we as entrepreneurs
have to figure out. And here we are in
2025 and you know we can go on chat GPT
or COD and and ask a whole bunch of
questions and get really smart really
quickly. But when when you were starting
your production studio that that wasn't
there. So like I mean just really basics
like how'd you learn how much to charge?
How did you learn about production
accounting? How did you actually build
the in as a creative? It's not obvious
that one would be great at doing that
too. Yeah. So h how did that play out
for you? I mean it was a lot of trial
and error. Like we started our company
with Legal Zoom, you know, so there were
resources like that that we could just
Yeah. Well, shout out Legal Zoom. Shout
out to Legal Zoom. And uh and and I
think honestly we like were severely
undercharging for a very long time. It I
think it helped us win business as a
young company. Um so but we were
scrambling also like we had other we
were working for other production
companies and such as well. Um, so we
had to learn. I think that was one of
the biggest things because as an artist
and I think anyone who's passionate
about their ideas, sometimes you're just
so excited to do it that you're like
whatever, I'll just do it for you. And
then um really when we started working,
I think maybe the first job we had that
our eyes were kind of open to that was
for Google up in you know, Mountain View
and just recognizing if you want to make
a living and you're working with
companies like that, you need to think
bigger. Um but even yeah I think also
markets change and so there is sort of I
feel like I'm always just eavesdropping.
I'm sort of like okay what are what are
you doing with your and what are we
doing now and you know um because I
didn't go to business school you know I
went to theater school and so we are we
are there is
a a trial and error but I think that's
okay like and I think that is part of
learning the value of your product you
have to kind of test and say okay this
budget everyone's saying yes to without
negotiating maybe we could go a little
higher you know maybe we can um see
value in that. Yeah. And what what's
been different for you about being in
Georgia with Trilith um than it was
being in Los Angeles?
Quality of life here has shot through
the roof. You know, um we have a much
bigger, nicer home than we would have,
you know. Um we honestly we love our
kids. Our kids are at the forest school
at Trillith. They're having an
incredible time. And it's funny, it took
me a second to really wrap my head
around the curriculum and and kind of
every day I'm like, are we is this okay?
Are we are they flourishing? They really
like they're just like brilliant little
dudes. Everyone's just the southern
hospitality is very real. You know, it's
very friendly. It's very collaborative.
Um and so that's just been really
incredible to get some of our projects
off the ground, both some of our like
indie creative projects as well as our
client work. Oh, great. Um, I want to I
want to bring us home with a few
questions for each of you. So, I'm I'm
curious um as you reflect on your
careers, each of you, what's a moment
that stood out that was one moment that
was a real tipping point in in your
career? I had a very lucky moment um as
an actor, which is that Zack Snyder saw
me in a hummus commercial and then
wanted to work with me. So that I mean
sort of launched me as an actor a little
bit. Um I think in terms of my
production company um we're in an
interesting moment right now which is
exciting and and hopefully kind of will
be one of those moments where we are um
just thinking bigger and starting to
pitch bigger for our next films. And so
we have a feature right now um that
we're working on actually Lauren Pesky
uh one of the teachers at the Trillith
Institute. She's a local television
director. Um, and I met her through my
work with Women of Color Filmmaker. She
came on as an instructor for us. And,
um, so she's going to be directing.
Demetrius is producing. And, um, it's
about a a high school girls basketball
team and, um, based here in Atlanta and
Georgia. And so, it this is a big
moment, I'd say, for me as a producer to
come in and say, "Okay, I'm going to I'm
going to be brave. I'm going to think
bigger. I'm going to, you know, reach
out to um different types of people that
uh we're aiming to work with. And so I
feel like I'm in that moment right now.
Amazing. Frank, one moment for you.
Uh I was younger, much younger. Um on my
first film, I had raised money and that
uh and I had investors and I went to go
make the movie and I had one of those
moments where you realize I shouldn't be
doing this. I don't know what I'm doing.
And it was the first day of shooting and
I don't know what I'm doing. I'm a
complete impostor, right? I've never
made a movie. This is ridiculous. I'm
going to lose everybody's money. And I
started throwing up. So I every morning
I would throw up. Um
and and I I began to realize I my fear
was I what if this movie stops? What if
it stops? And Julie Corman said to me,
"You're thinking about it all wrong."
It's
funded. It's going to get made. It's
just on you how good it's going to get
made. You know, it was just this relief
like, of course, this is going to get
made. I got to wake up here. And then
one of the investors, Mr. Winter, said,
"I didn't invest in you so you could
throw up." You know, I invested in you
because I believe in what you can do.
You know, so it was just sort of this
wake up, be, you know, yeah, embrace the
opportunity. And and and so since then,
it's just been like I got to believe in
myself, right? Second uh question for
each of you. Um, uh, one thing that has
surprised you about the the industry,
social media has really surprised me. It
like when I was starting out, it was
much more just people sharing funny
photos at a bar and things like that.
And now, um, it really is such a huge
tool that, uh, artists and filmmakers
and businesses, um, really kind of have
to learn how to use and use well. And so
it's it's an amazing opportunity to be
able to market for yourself in that way.
Um it's an amazing place for artists.
You know, we released our first projects
on YouTube and you know, we're able to
share them with the world that way. Um
and so I think that that's just been a
really neat and um surprising thing that
has radically transformed the
entertainment industry. Yeah.
And you know, building on that, I'm
often just surprised at how boldly, you
know, I I love the young filmmakers or
the young storytellers, the young
entrepreneurs that like, nope, doesn't
matter how it's done, I'm doing it. And
that's that's
really important. Um, we have uh a
number of early stage founders in the
room. Um, super grateful, by the way, to
our partner, Capital One Business, that
um helps bring early stage founders to
events like this. Um, brings them to our
summit in October in San Francisco. By
the way, the deadline for applications
is coming up. If you want to apply,
please do. Um uh and and and we have a
lot of them in our audience because
they're coming and looking for just that
one nugget, that one bit of advice that
is going to get them over a hurdle, get
them through a hard day, help them solve
a problem that they have no earthly idea
how they're going to solve it. So, if
there's a piece of advice that you can
offer to those early stage founders who
are who are with us, what's that advice?
Uh, Jim Bernie, are you here? Stand up
for me if you don't mind. I'm sorry to
put you on the spot. How old are you,
Jim?
Okay. Jim's 59. 59.
You're in the middle of a startup right
now called What?
Do you know how we're going to be
successful? You have it figured out?
Okay, that guy has done more businesses.
All right, so so just just to recap, 24
watts. 24 watts. It's a kids company, by
the way. 24 watts is the amount of
energy the human brain expends when
you're feeling inspired. Uh it's a
beautiful kids company. We make great
content, blah blah blah. That is one of
the smartest human beings in the world.
He doesn't know how he's going to
succeed, right? So no one knows. just
keep pivoting, keep looking till you get
that, you know, product market fit or
whatever it is that you're trying to do.
And then, by the way, then you can work
on scale. And you're not alone. And it's
always scary and there's really tough
nights, but it's a club. The um the
great author Eel Doctoro had a line that
I'm going to paraphrase because I won't
I won't nail it. Um he said, "Writing is
like driving at night. You can only see
as far as the headlights show you, but
somehow you make your way home." Somehow
you make your way home. Yeah. Um so that
that story reminds me of that. Uh thank
you Jim. Um Christina, one piece of
advice. M mine is fairly similar. Um but
I think you know all of us are so unique
and distinct and figuring out really
what is the most specific, the most
distinct thing that you are passionate
about that you bring to the table that
your um background offers you and focus
in on that because there are so many
creatives, so many startups, so many
businesses. But when you can figure out
where is the need and how you can fill
it and just keep iterating, keep, you
know, honing that um rather than trying
to watch someone else's success and be
like, "Oh, that was cool. Let me, you
know, mimic that or whatever." Yeah.
